comments.body: Nice and ambient. I like it!

This is fantastic because it would add a hint of realism and will allow players to enjoy the Minecraft sounds in different ways they've never heard before.

This suggestion boils down to making the "SOUND PHYSICS" mod vanilla.

Cosmetic/Aesthetic aspects of the game that do not influence mechanics are a good area for the MODDING COMMUNITY to be in charge of. How your client interprets and processes environmental sound doesn't change what it's like for other players to play the game with you in any statistically significant way.

Let's keep Mojang focused on MECHANICAL areas of the game, and leave superficial stuff to the modding community.
This would definitely make it better.
Amazing!!
Realistic. I like it.
This would be really cool thing to do in minecraft Who is this game is missing out on a lot of the sound effects
Nice idea!
Yea, low-pass sounds always make my day

I'm dreaming of this to mask the horrendous racket that is coming from my piston machines. Blocks could have a new sound muffling property akin to blast resistance. This property would determine the curve of the low-pass or high-pass filter applied to the sound. I'd then coat my machines in wool and stone to silence them.
That is actually really smart.  It would feel ambient, claustrophobic, and beautiful.  Especially if you are swimming in a coral reef.
also reverb
Would be really good for this to be added. Its already been implemented as a mod with the sound filters mod so it's clearly within the capabilities of the engine.

if it is raining and you are under water the rain sounds will be muffled, same applies for if your under a roof although this is a little less muffled. i like the idea though and agree!

I like the idea itself- and there are some impressive modifications out there that add a more complex sound system, giving reverb in caves, and muffling sounds based on proximity and obstruction. That being said, such a system tends to be performance heavy, and I imagine implementing it would be difficult. 

Still, I think some sort of improvements could be made to the existing sound system. ...I don't see it as the biggest priority ever, but I certainly wouldn't mind, and it definitely adds some more atmosphere to caving- which, admittedly, should be pretty interesting either way with the upcoming update.

This would be great idea but sounds like a nightmare to make work. Also would add just one more performance thing for computer to use to lag. However, I do wish when you heard a mob in caves you could pinpoint the sound better. Sometime there is a spawner but you can‚Äôt tell what direction or how far away. I thought maybe Mojang could alter zombie sounds specifically at least. Maybe they make a lower growl when farther from the player but increase to that more snappy sound they currently make when the player is in certain range. This I think would be a little less intensive work for them and your computer.
YES YES YES and with the new HRTF in the game this could take that to the next level since we'd have surround sound and sound occlusion.

In 1.19 they're adding HRTF audio and if they added this along with it the sounds in this game would be even more incredible

I heard that Mojang doesn't want to add "ambient" sounds to the game because they want every sound to have a source (ie. if you hear birds in the distance, you should be able to follow the sound and find.. birds!) The problem is that Minecraft sounds are lacking realism. Sounds that are far away, or underground, or behind something, don't really sound as such. This suggestion, if implemented properly, would add that much needed ambience while staying true to Mojang's vision.
Should be easier with 'new' ray-tracing, allowing you to detect blocks between player and sound source.

I believe a better way of implementation would be to have a 'recorder' that records any sounds nearby, and then can play them back. Note blocks included. Or maybe record a note block contraption. Whatever the case, the idea has merit.

My idea from my post (Which got deleted for some reason.) was: You can use a grindstone to turn any music disc (Even custom ones.) into blank discs. When put into a recording thing, it will record all note block and jukebox sounds for a maximum of 6 minutes. (As the longest music disc currently in game is 5:45) You can take it out at any time, and it will only end up playing for however long you leave it in. If you leave it in past 6 minutes, it simply will remain in the recorder until taken out, and the extra time in the recorder won't affect the song. As I stated earlier in this very lengthy comment, it will only pick up the jukebox and note block sounds, and since they are tracked separately from the other in game sounds, it won't be too difficult to implement. When you take it out, a gui will open up, and you can name it. The inner rim can also can be dyed to any of the 16 colors. It would also be able to be copied the same way a book can. The reason this will be balanced, is that you still have to build the note block machine to be able to record the song in the first place.
Aye, great idea. This is important to some music creators (like me) and it would be fun to be able to hear music other than the stuff on the original music discs. What about importing MIDI?

I really agree, this would allow players to become even more creative with music. It would basically make music easier to compose as there is no longer a need to take up hundreds of blocks with noteblocks, but noteblocks would have to be used until you got to endgame, as you said.

Could you also please go a bit more into depth about the MIDI? Would we be able to add layers for each instrument and maybe duplicate instruments (maybe these instruments are the blocks which we have to insert?). And how would we choose the note pitch and length?

 

Edit: After reading through the comments, I agree an emerald could be an alternative. And maybe actually composing the song will take up a diamond/emerald and the respective block?

Also, recording voices would not be such a great idea. On a private server with people you trust it may be alright, but people could really ruin it. People can be really horrible and allowing us to record voices would give them more oppurtunities to do so.

Neat idea.

The recorder should require resources to make the music with:

  • Insert blocks to add different instruments (corresponding to the sound noteblocks make when stacked on them)
  • It will consume noteblocks to add notes to the music.

There will be a data limit if it is encoded in the NBT data (similar to the NBT data limit on books).

I like it but maybe instead of being super expensive and endgame its endgame without being super duper expensive and the composing thing is a bit un-minecrafty so maybe instead it opens a window and you have to click and drag a .ogg file just to make it simpler for those of us who are musically un talented

Maybe not really a GUI.

In my opinion, it doesn't fit into Minecraft that way. So I propose this:

Disc recorder is an item that you put a disc into via crafting it with it (no changes about obtaining both, Diamond block and Charged Creeper kill is good). Then, you can move into your noteblock creation, play it and rightclick with the recorder. Then you keep walking alongside the blocks (recorder only captures noteblocks in range of, say, 30 blocks?) and record the track to it's end and rightclick again. Disc pops out and you have your own Music disc that is basically a small version of your noteblock song. You can then duplicate it like books, by putting an Empty disc and Music disc in crafting grid.

Technical stuff:

It should be saved in a format similar to MIDI - by that I mean no "actual music", just when and how noteblocks play. Other way, you can easily grow Minecraft a server world up to gigabytes. Also, duplicating doesn't make a new Music ID.

A limit of lenght is absolutely needed. I suggest maybe 10 minutes? That's up to Mojang tho.
Voiceover would be impossible to add. Not all platforms have a microphone.

This Guy: I want Music disc recorder!

Resource Pack Creator: We have Music disc recorder at home.

Music Disc Recorder:
My idea is you unlock sounds when you hear them in the game, like creeper explosion, cave sounds, and even party pillagers.

Yes!
Custom music disks are a great idea!
You should also make it so music disks can play on PE.

So, how I think this should work is thus: 
You craft a "recorder" or "microphone" block. 
When the recorder is placed in a mine cart and sent down a track with attached note blocks, it records the sounds of only the note blocks as it passes by, with a duration that matches the length of the mine cart track. 
If placed outside a mine cart, it would record all ambient sounds. 
From there, just take the custom vinyl out of the recorder block and put it in the jukebox to play it. 

You could also use a "Mixer" block, which would have an interface similar to the Anvil where you could combine two tracks together using another empty vinyl. This way, players could make more elaborate tracks and even somewhat remix the tracks that are already in the game. 

I don't think the empty vinyl tracks should be quite so difficult to obtain though. Making them craft-able would be preferred. I wouldn't think of a blank vinyl as a rare reward, as it wouldn't do anything for players that don't want to make their own music. 

One of the coolest uses I can foresee for this is adding a musical jingle to secret piston doors.

I just hate the idea of a vinyl recorder when there's already noteblocks. maybe a noteblock string of music can be recorded attaching the circuit with a jupebox already having the empty disc.when the music in the contraption is over the redstone sends the signal and the empty disc pops out recorded the music.

Some of these ideas have already been said by some comments:

The "Recorder Block" could be craftable with diamond, maybe redstone, amethyst shards and a sculk sensor;
Only if it has a "Record disk" and powered by a redstone signal will activate;
Also, a "Recorder on Minecart" should start to record when it passes through a activator rail, and stops when it passes another time;
The disks used to record maybe have to be found in end cities only;
"Sign" a disk will lock it. Meaning that you have to find another one to record again;
Only sounds of noteblocks could be recorded;
The Recorder itself should be easier to get rather than disks, like for decorative purposes.
The Recorder should be able to record many different noteblocks sounds at same time.
"Record disks" shouldn't lock when the Recorder stops, meaning that you can try different times to improve the recorded disk sound.
"Locked recorded disks" should stack and can be duplicated in anvils with a non locked disk.

Recording noteblocks music and sounds will be a great mechanic to the gameplay. We already have a way to make custom paints with maps, and if we can do the same with music, the game will be a lot more artistic and fun.

I think the different instruments should be the different note blocks, so it would give note block music creators an interesting way to make music. While making it portable and such.

You can make custom music discs if you go into the Minecraft files and delete a music disc recording and replace it with an OGG file of your own.  I made lots of my music discs into my favorite country songs.

New?:

Empty vinyls are special, unmarked music-disc-like items dropped after a skeleton fatally shoots a charged creeper. A vinyl recorder is crafted with an amethyst shard in the center, a jukebox in the middle top, redstone dust in the middle bottom, Nether quartz on the bottom corners, and copper ingots everywhere else (to give it more use and also give it a fresh new look).

The recorder GUI can contains a vinyl slot. After inserting the empty vinyl, it brings up a MIDI-like interface. You can arrange songs using the user-friendly interface, using different tones and sounds of note blocks and some in-game sounds to create new music. You can save a vinyl as a "Draft Disc", which can be taken out and returned to the recorder without risk of losing your progress. You can save the disc and name it like books, and give it an author. You can craft it with different ores and dyes to give it a different color as the inner-hole-band, though the record itself is always the default black. You can re-insert it into the recorder and "Un-save" to edit the disc.

Records can be copied by placing a filled vinyl and an empty vinyl into crafting slots.

Technically the Ender Dragon has a boss theme, it's mostly ambience, but that's just the kinda game Minecraft is.

I can't see the Wither having a boss theme.

Minecraft's music is about flexibility. It can play anytime, anywhere, and can still fit the mood. I think adding action packed boss themes would break this rule a little bit. Think about it. All music covers very vague and basic themes. Overworld, Underwater, Nether. Because that's all it needs. Either way I totally agree that C418 should make more music for Minecraft. As far as I know he made some more music for Minecraft but Microsoft wants to buy his music and not have a license to use it which is where the problem is.

I mean the new soundtracks are okay but they just don't fit into the game as well as C418's. You can see the new ones tried to replicate the feel of the original but it just doesn't feel right. C418's music was either mysterious or just calming while the new soundtracks feel sad.

First of all, yes, C148 is a legend, I would love to see him return, with all the other people who are now also working on the OST as well, however, C148 wants to own his music, and Microsoft wants to own his music rights. That is a huge conflicting value, in my opinion if C148 shall return (which he wants to), Microsoft really should let it go, even if it isn't in their capitalistic nature to do so. 

Secondly, they really should have allowed Mojang to make that decision for Minecraft. Microsoft just isn't interested though, and that's really sad. For a company that loves to advertise creativity and progress, they also inhibit those things.

Thirdly, the list of songs above by another Registered User were never removed from the game. 100% a lie. 

 

Lastly, if Microsoft REALLY does not want to let go of the rights, I may offer multiple solutions:

  • A 60:40 split of the rights, C148:Microsoft

  • No rights go to Microsoft but Microsoft earns 65-75% revenue made off of the song on Streaming Services.

  • Continue to use the current license they had and let it go, it's probably cheap as hell if the contract has not expired or been voided.

  • Simply attempt to work it out with him without bringing the idea of lawyers like you did last time.

While these new compositions emulate the feeling of C148's music very well, that's all they are. Emulations. I really wish that Microsoft could realize their mistake in removing him from any future compositions.
Eh, It would be Nice if C418, Lena and Kumi Tanioka all made music for Minecraft instead of Microsoft cherry picking.

I couldn't agree more. I have a lot to say about this and I think it's worth me sharing, and somebody at Microsoft taking it into consideration. 

C418's music isn't just a part of Minecraft. It's absolutely integral to making Minecraft what it is. It is truly one of the defining features of this game, and is just as responsible for its "magic" as the visual style is. Changing the music is akin to changing the shape of the blocks. It's just not as obvious.

Since the past couple updates, I've been less and less interested in playing. Something about the way the game feels now is just different. It doesn't invoke that feeling of mystery and ethereal calm. 

I'd get motivated to play, and then would feel tired of it within an hour. I couldn't understand why, and I genuinely thought about it a lot. But every time I'd play, something felt off and triggered a feeling of withdrawal. It's a subtle but profound sense of something being missing.

Then one day, it hit me. As I was playing, that "Infinite Amethyst" song came on again, and I realized it was triggering these feelings. The repetitive, anxiety inducing, droning note that just never ends, and the overly loud swell of notes that always makes me turn the volume down in frustration. It's an assault on the senses that just does not fit. It completely takes me out of the game. 

Later when talking to my son about how Minecraft doesn't feel the same, his first comment was "yeah the new music is annoying. I just don't like it anymore"

This must be done!
New players of minecraft should understand that the magic of music in the world of minecraft was in the hand of who is no more. :(

I do think that Lena Raine work on the music discs ‚ÄúPigStep‚Äù and ‚Äú OtherSide‚Äù are great there both a bop while still sounding somewhat similar to C418‚Äôs music discs. However I strongly believe that Lena Raine should not be working on the soundtrack for the game, don‚Äôt get me wrong I think she has done some great work on other games but C418 cannot be replaced

You could say that because so many new biomes have been added it‚Äôs time for new music to be added, I do agree with this but Mojang should get C418 back as they have done before with the Aquatic update.

Lena Raine should still come out with new discs but I and the people who I have spoken  too feel that C418‚Äôs music just can‚Äôt be properly replicated without distracting from the game. If he is brought back I think the community will be happy to see his return.

I believe this already happens in Java edition 1.13+ if you're wearing headphones, but it also causes the sounds to seem slightly muffled.

Currently, realistic sounding games are really hard to make. The most realistic method we have is path tracing (path tracing is used for lighting but can also be used to model sound waves) which is very computationally expensive.

Fighting music has already been considered and rejected. I roughly quote C418, "We considered adding fighting music, but most battles only last for a few seconds, and nobody wants to listen to epic battle music for just five seconds." 

In addition, this would really break up the ambient piece of Minecraft. It would encourage you to get drawn into a fight with every mob you see, which isn't something I specifically think should be discouraged, but I quite prefer to be able to go along peacefully without any nagging. Not everyone spends all their time in survival going out in search of combat.

The fact that physical barriers of any type have no effect on sound in the game has always bothered me, and I think is something they should look at changing. You should not be able to hear a minecart rolling under 10 layers of solid stone, a 2 wide wooden wall should at least muffle the sound of a minecart rolling by on a sugarcane farm and animals outside. I would say sound should function similarly to how light spreads, but the lag caused by many light update blocks is already detrimental to lower end devices. However if they made it possible to change settings for this, this issue could be mitigated

I think mineral wool should be added instead of this suggestion. Wool is a great building block, so I think some people might not like this.
Thanks for coming up with this, though. Even though I saw a tiny problem with your suggestion, you still came up with maybe the first idea of a soundproofing block, and if we all encourage the Minecraft community to come up with ideas for sound insulation, you might be the one who fixes the problem with loud animal farms.
I agree, and just so builders and redstoners can still build with wool as they have before, why not wool bales? Craft 2 x 2 of a wool type to get a wool bale of a matching type.
My dumb as thought this was already a feature and encased a 20x20x20 cube with all animal farms with wool. Lol ! It should have been how wool works with the recent update!
this is a great idea and it's weird to me that it hasn't been already in the game

I think this is a great idea, in fact I was surprised when I tried encasing a chicken farm in wool and it did nothing.  I agree that there may need to be a new block, perhaps an insulation block that could be crafted using wool and something like paper

I agree with this. I love to build and create on Minecraft, and I love the way you can build both in creative (selecting whatever blocks you want) and survival (where there is a recipe to build and create).

I also enjoy the challenge of trying to survive along with hostile mobs, such as zombies and creepers and spiders and so on. I wish there was a way I could enjoy all of these things and have a more natural sound in the background as opposed to the screams, eerie voices, and haunting sounds that I hear wherever I am, even if I am not in a cave or the nether or at the end.

Could there maybe be a game mode the player can choose that takes out the cave sounds (i.e. the eerie unnatural sounds) and simply keeps all the other sounds, such as the noises of animals and water and blocks and such? Or simply a selection to turn off the cave sounds, something that allows those who simply want to build the option to continue to enjoy building.
This is much needed for people with anxiety disorders

This is definitely needed in every edition as I can imagine younger audiences being frightened and put off by these eerie ambient sounds. I myself not only find them disturbing, but also annoying as I spend a lot of time in caves mining diamonds and redstone. At first, when you enter a cave and hear one of the sounds, it adds intensity to the game and initiates that 'fight or flight response'; however, after the 20th time it becomes a bit unnecessary as there is no immediate threat and it puts me on edge for no reason as I am an experienced solo player, so I can handle myself well in these cave systems.

As I am a console player, I remember on some of the older versions there was an option to remove ambient sounds by ticking a box, however bedrock edition does not have this feature as of yet. I also play with headphones, so you can imagine how much anxiety this gives me!

I think adding this tickbox or slider to the audio section will benefit both parties as those who do not like them can turn them off. As for those who enjoy these sounds because it adds intensity and immersion to the game, they can choose to keep them on by default. This slider wouldn't just be for cave sounds, it would also be for nether and aquatic sounds as well.

The ambient sounds are so good but the cave sounds are too creppy and I can't play with having fun because I really scared of them
I really want that mojang remove horrible cave sounds
I never go to caves before the remove them heh üòÇ

Yes yes yes! This would be perfect for the new combat system that's coming up. I also have an idea saying that different weapons should make different sounds so I hope that both of our ideas get added :)
